indicators.justification:
The Saint Lucia National Environment Management System (NEIS) was developed by the government as a Project Reporting System for Multilateral Environmental Agreement (MEA) Implementation and Environmental Information Management. Unfortunately, there are no open datasets currently available on the website. (1)

(1)Saint Lucia National Environment Management System (NEIS)https://www.neis.govt.lc/

indicators.justification:
The Registry of Companies (ROCIP) is the agency responsible for registration of all businesses in Saint Lucia. Currently, ROCIP does not make data on beneficial ownership of companies public as structured open data. ROCIP does have a website that is intended to facilitate an online name search, but this only allows for one to view the names of a business and not any further details.(1)

Sources:
(1)The Official Website of the Saint Lucia Registry of Companies. http://www.rocip.gov.lc/stlucia/

indicators.justification:
The Registry of Companies (ROCIP) is the agency responsible for registration of all businesses in Saint Lucia. Currently, ROCIP does not make data on beneficial ownership of companies public as structured open data. ROCIP does have a website that is intended to facilitate an online name search, but this only allows for one to view the names of a business and not any further details. Also, these listings are not provided as Open data(1).

Sources:
(1)Registry of Companies Website. http://www.rocip.gov.lc/stlucia/

indicators.justification:
There is no real-time data on the capacity of the healthcare system, neither as open data or otherwise.

The responses in this section are based on some annual data available on bed capacity of the main hospital made available by the Central Statistics Office here: https://www.stats.gov.lc/subjects/society/health/number-of-hospitals-and-institutions-by-bed-capacity-1982-to-2020/. Note that the bed capacity is only based on data collected from one hospital (the largest of the 7 on island).

It is notable that there is regular reporting on the Covid19 Cases by the Government as seen here:https://www.covid19response.lc/

indicators.justification:
The Land Registry is the agency responsible for the registration of all dealings in land, and interest in land.  The agency is mandated to maintain an index of all the names of proprietors of land and leases. Land tenure information in Saint Lucia is not available online or in electronic format. It must be accessed by visiting the office and paying a fee of EC$10.00 to receive a paper copy of the relevant land registration document as requested.(1)
Note however, that the Land Registry which is responsible for Land tenure, publishes aggregate data on its transactions on the Open Data website here: https://data.govt.lc/dataset/land-registry-monthly-transactions.
Also, they have begun the process of digitizing their records. This process is still ongoing   and upon completion the land data will be available in electronic format.

Sources:
(1) Guidance on Requesting A Copy of a Land Registry, Government of Saint Lucia, http://www.govt.lc/services/request-a-copy-of-a-land-registry-document

responses.subquestion_text: Is this data available online in any form?
There is structured data available on the executive budget proposal in gross terms, including spending on annual and multi-annual investment projects.
There is structured data available on amended budgets (when applicable) or amendments of the enacted budget.
There is structured data available on the approved or enacted budget in gross terms, including spending on annual and multi-annual investment projects.
There is structured data about government budget execution or spending, in gross terms and on an accrual basis, including spending in annual and multi-annual investment projects.
There is structured data about the government's extrabudgetary funds spending, in gross terms and on an accrual basis.
There is structured data about the government's social security spending, in gross terms and on an accrual basis.
There is structured data about public corporations' spending, in gross terms and on an accrual basis.
Budget entries have administrative classifications to an internationally agreed standard.
Budget entries have economic classifications to an internationally agreed standard.
Budget entries have functional classifications to an internationally agreed standard.
Budget entries have program classifications according to an internationally agreed standard.
Information about individual financial transactions or expenditures is available at the most disaggregated level of the economic classification level.
Data is disaggregated by cross-cutting programs, or issues such as SDGs, climate action, gender budgeting, etc,
The data contains common identifiers to connect budget and budget performance data.
The data contains identifiers that can be used to connect budget data with data on major projects (e.g., infrastructure construction) and procurement processes.
Dataset is available free of charge.
Data is openly licensed.
Data is available in all the country’s official or national languages. If the country has no official or national languages, data is available in the major languages of the country.
There are accessible and open official tools available to help users explore data.

indicators.justification:
The Integrity Commission collects data on interest and asset declaration data in Saint Lucia. The Commission tables a yearly report in parliament and some of the information from this report, specifically the list of names and posts officials who have failed to submit declarations as per the Act, is published periodically in the Saint Lucia Government Gazette.(1)
Source
"Integrity Commission Report", July 06, 2020 Gazette here:http://www.slugovprintery.com/template/files/gazettes/2020/july/Gazette%20July%206%202020.pdf

indicators.justification:
Political Parties are not currently obligated to publish any campaign financing data as per the Elections Act(1) which governs elections in Saint Lucia. Political finance data was not published on the websites either of the three major political parties which contested the 2021 Saint Lucia elections: Saint Lucia Labour Party(2), United Workers Party(3) and the National Green Party (4).
Sources:
(1)Elections Act, 2008. https://www.iidh.ed.cr/capel2016/media/1131/election-act.pdf
(2)Saint Lucia Labour Party Website. https://voteslp.org/
(3)United Workers Party Website. https://uwpstlucia.com/
(4)National Green Party Website. https://www.ngp.lc/

Data includes unique identifiers for each donor.

indicators.justification:
The collection of public consultation information is not required by law, but is sometimes provided by the government agencies as good practice.(1) There are individually published notices in the media by agencies (2) which may decide to execute consultations for their specific causes (laws, policies, regulations, strategies, plans). Bills are also sometimes made available online as part of a broader consultation process (3). The Attorney General Chambers also publishes the list of Bills currently under development by government agency responsible (4).
Sources:
(1)http://www.govt.lc/news/about/law-legislation#
(2)https://www.finance.gov.lc/programmes/view/128
   http://www.govt.lc/news/cannabis-commission-hosts-national-consultations
(3)http://www.govt.lc/legislations?sort=newest
   http://www.govt.lc/legislation/electronic-crimes-bill
(4)https://attorneygeneralchambers.com/p/legislation-by-ministry-or-department

indicators.justification:
The Saint Lucia Open Data Policy speaks to supporting data re-use in Section 5.8 "Promoting Open Data"; which outlines a mandate to promote open data within government, in parastatals and outside government. (1) Also, the government partnered with regional and external agencies to hold the Saint Lucia leg of the regional Devca Hackathon in May 2019.(2)
Sources:
(1)http://www.govt.lc/media.govt.lc/www/resources/publications/open-data-policy-final-appr.pdf
(2)http://www.govt.lc/news/devca-2019-headed-for-saint-lucia

responses.response_text: There is some evidence of government supporting and encouraging data reuse.

responses.response_text: Support assessed is at national level.
responses.subquestion_text: How comprehensive, in terms of jurisdiction, is the coverage of the support assessed for this question?

indicators.justification:
Although there is exists evidence of a well-funded open data programme in Saint Lucia, supported by an Open data Policy, the Open data portal itself shows evidence of being poorly maintained and has a lack of data updates. Examining the webpage of the Division of Public Sector Modernisation (2) which is the coordinating agency for the Open Data programme and also reviewing the Estimates of Expenditure 2020-21 (3) confirms that there is evidence of a previously well-resourced programme, but there is a lack of more recent or updates efforts in this regard.
Sources:
(1)https://data.govt.lc/
(2)http://www.govt.lc/ministries/public-service-information-and-broadcasting/public-sector-modernisation

responses.response_text: There has been a government-led open government data initiative, but there is limited evidence of recent activity.
responses.subquestion_text: Has there been any form of government-led open government data initiative during the study period?
There is a government team in place supporting open data activities.
There is an allocated budget for open data activities.
There is a well-maintained open data portal.
There is guidance and support for government publication of open data.
Senior political leaders back the open data initiative.

responses.response_text: The open data initiative covers only a limited part of the national government, but there are similar initiatives for many other parts of government.
responses.subquestion_text: How widely does this, or similar, open data initiatives apply?

indicators.justification:
In Saint Lucia local government consists of one city council in Castries(1) which is the country's only city and 14 town and village councils(2). The local government do not publish or share data online; and demonstrate little capability or efforts towards the collection and management of data. The efforts at data management are focused with central government through the Department of Public Service (3) and the Central Statistics Office.(4)
Sources:
(1)http://www.cityofcastries.org/
(2)http://atlasflacma.weebly.com/uploads/5/0/5/0/5050016/st_lucia_local_government_profile_2011-12.pdf
(3)https://data.govt.lc/
(4)https://www.stats.gov.lc/

responses.response_text: There is no evidence of capability to effectively manage data.

There is evidence of local governments having rules and or guidance in place for consistent data management and publication.
There is evidence of local governments providing training to civil servants on data literacy and skills.
There is evidence of local governments providing support for data reuse.

responses.response_text: No cities or regions show capacity to effectively manage data.

indicators.justification:
The evidence of training in data literacy and data skills was found in the Training Catalogue of the Saint Lucia Public Service Training Institute(1), which not only detailed several data-related training courses, but also provided a report on participation during the previous year. Additional evidence of such training found online was a data collection training course executed by the Department of Sustainable Development to facilitate the National Environment Information System (NEIS) (2).
Sources
(1)Training Catalogue of the Saint Lucia Public Service Training Institute 2019-2020. http://www.govt.lc/publications/training-catalogue-2019-2020
(2)"Training of Stakeholders from Department of Sustainable Development," 2019. https://www.facebook.com/447248662058942/posts/further-training-of-stakeholders-in-data-management-from-the-department-of-susta/2294837603966696/

indicators.justification: Due to the unavailability of political integrity data, it was not feasible to execute this segment.

responses.response_text: The datasets do not share common identifiers.
responses.subquestion_text: There is evidence that datasets share common identifiers.
The key datasets for this theme share common identifiers that facilitate mapping flows across the data ecosystem.
The different political integrity datasets use common identifiers for public officials.
Lobbying data and political finance data share common identifiers for lobbyist clients and party and campaign donors.
Lobbying registers and public consultation data use common identifiers for regulations.
Asset declarations and political finance disclosures share common identifiers for interests, assets, and liabilities.
The various datasets share common identifiers for legal persons associated with donations, interests, assets, liabilities, and lobbying activities.
The key datasets for the political integrity and company information modules share common identifiers that facilitate mapping flows across the data ecosystem.
The key datasets for the political integrity and land modules share common identifiers that facilitate mapping flows across the data ecosystem.
The key datasets for the political integrity and public finance modules share common identifiers that facilitate mapping flows across the data ecosystem.
The key datasets for the political integrity and public procurement modules share common identifiers that facilitate mapping flows across the data ecosystem.

indicators.justification:
The Registry of Companies, headed by the Registrar, is tasked with registering companies in Saint Lucia. Currently, there is not yet a move to publish data on beneficial owners of companies in Saint Lucia. The Companies (Amendment) Act(1) and the Companies (Amended) Regulations 2020 (2) includes the requirement for a register of beneficial ownership to be filed with the Registrar of Companies when incorporating private sector companies. It also requires each company to keep their own register of beneficial ownership but does not mandate the Registrar to keep a central register. Further, it does not speak to making data on beneficial ownership public.

Sources:
(1)The Companies Act (Amended), 2020. http://slugovprintery.com/template/files/document_for_sale/laws/4259/Act%2010%20of%202018.pdf
(2)The Companies (Amended) Regulations, 2020. http://slugovprintery.com/template/files/document_for_sale/laws/4676/SI%20171%20of%202020.pdf

indicators.justification:
Although Saint Lucia ratified the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with disabilities in 2020 (1), there have been no frameworks developed specifically to address the needs of persons with disabilities as it relates to the access to data. However, within the Data Protection Act(2), there are provisions which facilitate allowances for persons with sensory disabilities.
Sources:
(1) "Government of Saint Lucia Ratifies the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities (CRPD)", 2020. http://www.govt.lc/news/government-of-saint-lucia-ratifies-crpd
(2) Data Protection Act, 2011. https://www.dataguidance.com/sites/default/files/act_11_of_2011.pdf

The rules/guidance empower an agency or official to ensure the accurate and timely collection and publication of required data.

indicators.justification:
There is no framework which is solely focused on consistent management and publication of data in Saint Lucia. The standards for the management of specifically open data is covered in the Open data policy (1), but it does not apply to data in general. The Statistics Act speaks to data management to an extent and this is highlighted in the preamble as an Act "to provide for the collection compilation and analysis of certain statistical information including the taking of statistical information including the taking of census and the publication of that information for matters relating thereto." (2)

Sources:
(1) Saint Lucia Open Data Policy,2017. http://www.govt.lc/publications/saint-lucia-open-data-policy
(2) Saint Lucia Statistics Act, 2001. https://www.stats.gov.lc/wp-content/uploads/2018/05/CSO_StLucia_Statistics_Act_Chapter_17.12_Vol._19_of_2001.pdf

responses.subquestion_text: What is the nature of the framework?

There are technical standards, including common data models, codelists, and identifiers for management and publication of government data.
There are clearly documented quality control processes for government data.
There are clearly documented processes for soliciting and integrating feedback from external users to improve data quality.

responses.response_text: The data management approaches assessed generally apply across the whole public sector.

The Saint Lucia Open Data policy speaks specifically to open data, but there exists a void as it relates to data-sharing in general, and specifically non-open data.(1)

indicators.justification:
The Data Protection Act is the singular piece of legislation or policy which speaks specifically to the protection of personal data privacy in Saint Lucia. It does, however, still require the establishment of the Data Commissioner office for full enforcement.

indicators.justification:
Saint Lucia has the official language of English and the widely used Kweyol language. There is no document that currently speaks to obligations related to language in the publication of data. The National Language Policy(1) is still in draft and if updated to include processes related to data collection and publication, it can provide for a notable framework for this purpose in the future.

(1)Draft Saint Lucia National Language Policy, 2020. https://camdu.edu.lc/wp-content/uploads/2020/12/Draft-Saint-Lucia-National-Language-Policy.pdf

indicators.justification:
The Finance (Administration) Act of Saint Lucia, mandates the collection of data and the preparation of Estimates of Revenue and Expenditure (Section 19) to be presented to the House of Assembly.(1) This does not specify the format for reporting or any guidance regarding publishing. The Saint Lucia Open Data Policy refers to the publication of all types of government data in public format.(2)

(1)The Finance Administration Act, 2014. http://portal.oas.org/en/sla/dlc/mesicic/docs/mesicic5_sl_anexo3.pdf

In Saint Lucia, the Integrity in Public Life Act Chapter 1.19 (1) requires to the collection of data on the interests and assets of public officials. However, there is no requirement for this data to be published.

indicators.justification:
In Saint Lucia, there are no laws, policies or regulations requiring the collection or publication of data on campaign and party finance. The Electoral process in Saint Lucia is governed by the Electoral Act along with the relevant official Regulation and Rules to give full effect of the Act.(1) These documents do not speak to campaign financing. There was also an amendment to the Election Act in 2016, which also does not mention campaign financing(2).

According to the publication "From Grassroots to the Airwaves: Paying for Political Parties and Campaigns in the Caribbean"(3) extensive research on the subject and revealed that although both of the political parties are okay with the idea of campaign financing, it is just not high on the party agendas and has not received much media attention. Indeed, in Saint Lucia it has been almost absent from the media recently, save for the 2017 declaration by the then Prime Minister that there is a need for laws on campaign financing (4).


Sources:
1) Consolidated Electoral Act and Related Regulations, 2008 Attached.
2)Election Amendment, 2016. Attached.
3)https://www.oas.org/sap/docs/publications/grassroots.pdf
4)https://stluciatimes.com/pm-favours-campaign-financing-laws/

evidence.title: Consolidated Electoral Act and Related Regulations

indicators.justification:
There is currently no framework on the collection and publication of data generated through and about public consultation on rulemaking. This was confirmed by the review of Saint Lucia's "Transparency and Rulemaking"(1) Further, the process for making legislation does not mandate public consultation, as specified by the Attorney General Chambers (2). Thus the decisions to consult publicly is left to the Government, or the Agency responsible for the piece of legislation. This has led to public debate on the issue (3) and official outcry when consultations are by-passed(4)
Sources
(1)Global Indicators of Regulatory Governance, World Bank. https://rulemaking.worldbank.org/en/data/explorecountries/st-lucia#cer_consultation
(2)Process for Making Legislation, Saint Lucia Attorney General Chambers. https://attorneygeneralchambers.com/document-categories/process-for-making-legislation#
(3)"Public Consultation in the Legislative Process in Saint Lucia: A Historical Perspective", By Claudius Francis -February 3, 2020. https://stluciastar.com/public-consultation-in-the-legislative-process-in-saint-lucia-a-historical-perspective/
(4)Saint Lucia Defends Covid Legislation, 2020. https://today.caricom.org/2020/09/30/saint-lucia-government-defends-covid-19-legislation/

indicators.justification:
Companies data is not currently available in electronic format. The information held by the company register is accessible, in hard copy, by visiting the Registry of Companies Office (ROCIP). There is a fee attached which is detailed in the Saint Lucia Company (amendment) Regulations of Statutory Instrument 2017 No. 33. See Regulation 27(1). There are Financial Services companies that execute due diligence on behalf of their clients, but they would complete this task by visiting the ROCIP office. International clients that are headquartering businesses in Saint Lucia are facilitated by a list of Local Registered Agents (LRAs) provided by the Saint Lucia International Financial Centre on their website(2).
Sources:
(1)http://slugovprintery.com/template/files/document_for_sale/laws/3776/S.I.%2033%20of%202016.pdf
(2)https://www.pinnaclestlucia.com/registry/list_rep.jsp?nextPage=rep_info.jsp

indicators.justification:
There is evidence of academics, multilateral agencies, and policy makers using this data to highlight environmental impacts of land use, such as on the water resources(1); and also land degradation(2). 
The media may also consult land tenure data in reports on land disputes(3) or what they deem to be questionable land acquisitions(4).

Sources:
(1)"Impact of Land Use change on Water Resources , Availability and Water Quality in Saint Lucia", Global Water Partnership (GWP), 2021. https://www.gwp.org/globalassets/global/gwp-c-files/gwp-c-persepctives-paper---impact-of-land-use-change-on-water-resources-availability-and-water-quality-in-saint-lucia.pdf
(2)
Government of Saint Lucia, Final Country Report of the Land Degradation Neutrality Target Setting Programme (LDN TSP), 2018.
https://knowledge.unccd.int/sites/default/files/ldn_targets/2019-03/Saint%20Lucia%20LDN%20TSP%20Country%20Report.pdf
(3)"Government Acquisition of Belair Lands", 
 2019. https://thevoiceslu.com/2019/08/govt-acquisition-of-belair-lands-foils-local-companies-plans/
(4)"New Developments in Anse Jambette Constroversy", 2021. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2_fmtVDkWFU

indicators.justification:
There is not a wealth of public integrity data available for the media and other researchers to "regularly use." However, the list of names of public officials which is published in PDF and in print by the Integrity Commission(1), though it is limited only to the names of the individuals and their posts in government, has occasionally been re-published by journalists and used as supporting evidence to call for greater transparency and accountability in government.(2)

Sources:
1)Government of Saint Lucia Gazette, July 06,2020, pp.847-853, http://www.slugovprintery.com/template/files/gazettes/2020/july/Gazette%20July%206%202020.pdf
2)https://www.facebook.com/watch/?v=226043775053781; 
  https://www.facebook.com/watch/?v=255406382471945
  https://thevoiceslu.com/2015/10/integrity-defaulters-published/
  https://www.facebook.com/watch/?v=226043775053781

responses.response_text: There are isolated cases of actors or entities using this kind of data for accountability purposes, though the source may not be open data.
responses.subquestion_text: Is there evidence of this data being used for accountability purposes?
Civil society organizations regularly use this data for accountability purposes.
The media regularly uses this data for accountability purposes.
Scholars or academic institutions regularly use this data for accountability purposes.
The private sector regularly uses this data for accountability purposes.
At least one of the examples identified describes using artificial Intelligence or machine learning to process data
There is evidence that these uses have had or are having meaningful positive impacts.

indicators.justification: There were no relevant use-cases identified for this section.

responses.response_text: There is no evidence of this use.
responses.subquestion_text: To what extent is there evidence of this kind of data use?
There is evidence of government procurement data being presented through data-driven dashboards.
There is evidence of government procurement data being used for red flag analysis.
There is evidence that government procurement data is being analyzed to improve access to procurement opportunities for marginalized groups.
There is evidence of government procurement data being analysed to support sustainable / environmental procurement.
There are examples of government using data in these ways.
There are examples of civil society using data in these ways.
There is evidence of private sector using data in this way
At least one of the examples cited appears to make use of open procurement data.
At least one of the examples identified makes use of open beneficial ownership data.
At least one of the examples identified describes using artificial Intelligence or machine learning to process data
There is evidence that these uses have had or are having meaningful positive impacts.

indicators.indicator_name: Capability (C): Political freedoms and civil liberties
Capability (C): Business use of digital tools
Capability (C): Use of standards and methods in statistic offices
Use (U): Data use by international organizations
